title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: automobile dataset contains 26 rows 205 observations. response variable price others explanatory variables. Load data:
code: data("automobile") head(automobile) #> # A tibble: 6 × 26 #>   symbol…¹ norma…² make  fuel-…³ aspir…⁴ num-o…⁵ body-…⁶ drive…⁷ engin…⁸ wheel…⁹ #>   <fct>      <dbl> <fct> <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>     <dbl> #> 1 3             NA alfa… gas     std     two     conver… rwd     front      88.6 #> 2 3             NA alfa… gas     std     two     conver… rwd     front      88.6 #> 3 1             NA alfa… gas     std     two     hatchb… rwd     front      94.5 #> 4 2            164 audi  gas     std     four    sedan   fwd     front      99.8 #> 5 2            164 audi  gas     std     four    sedan   4wd     front      99.4 #> 6 2             NA audi  gas     std     two     sedan   fwd     front      99.8 #> # … with 16 more variables: length <dbl>, width <dbl>, height <dbl>, #> #   `curb-weight` <dbl>, `engine-type` <fct>, `num-of-cylinders` <fct>, #> #   `engine-size` <dbl>, `fuel-system` <fct>, bore <dbl>, stroke <dbl>, #> #   `compression-ratio` <dbl>, horsepower <dbl>, `peak-rpm` <dbl>, #> #   `city-mpg` <dbl>, `highway-mpg` <dbl>, price <dbl>, and abbreviated #> #   variable names ¹​symboling, ²​`normalized-losses`, ³​`fuel-type`, ⁴​aspiration, #> #   ⁵​`num-of-doors`, ⁶​`body-style`, ⁷​`drive-wheels`, ⁸​`engine-location`, …

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: function saveVar() allows save column price .rds file. name end .rds empty, may cause error. Note out_dir path .Rproj. out_dir exists, new directory created function called.
code: saveVar(var = automobile$price, name = "price.rds", out_dir = "result") # will print "price.rds saved to your/absolute/path/.../result" # will return "price.rds saved to result"

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: function getR2() allows get \(R^2\) first n explanatory variables explain variations fitting OLS model. input variable n whole numbers 1 25.

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: function plotAll() visualize distribution chosen variables automobile. function returns list plots. make factor, hence presents barplot. engine-size continuous, hence presents histogram scatterplot linear regression line. One continuous variable takes two slots returned list.
code: plots <- plotAll(automobile, c("make","engine-size")) # access barplot for "make" plots[[1]] # access histogram for "engine-size" plots[[2]] # access scatterplot for "engine-size" plots[[3]]

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: , can call following functions get models predict car price. Firstly, since using cross-validation. split whole data frame training set testing set:
code: # By specifying the set = "basic", the result contains all columns training_df<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"basic")[[1]] testing_df<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"basic")[[2]]   # By specifying the set = "at", the result contains all columns except ID training_df_at<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"at")[[1]] testing_df_at<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"at")[[2]]  # By specifying the set = "sub", the result contains columns except ID or categorical variables with more than 2 levels training_df_sub<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"sub")[[1]] testing_df_sub<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"sub")[[2]]

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: Now can get matrices using get_trm_tsm() lasso ridge regression: Note 1 x, explanatory variables; 2 y, response. highly recommend using data frame excluding ID categorical variables 2 levels ensure interpretability.
code: # training matrices training_matrices <- get_trm_tsm(training_df_sub,                                   testing_df_sub,                                   set = "training") x_train_mat <- training_matrices[[1]] y_train_mat <- training_matrices[[2]]  # testing matrices testing_matrices <- get_trm_tsm(training_df_sub,                                  testing_df_sub,                                  set = "testing") x_test_mat <- testing_matrices[[1]] y_test_mat <- testing_matrices[[2]]

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: Use get_model_plot() function train models: ask = "modeling", return models; ask = "plot", fig_path = "analysis/figs", save result analysis/figs PNG. don’t specify fig_path, create analysis/figs directory save automatically. lasso regression: Similarly, ridge regression:
code: # Lasso regression lasso_mods <-   get_model_plot(x_train_mat,                   y_train_mat,                   model = "lasso",                   ask = "modeling")  # model with lambda resulting in minimum mse lasso_mod <- lasso_mods[[1]]  # model with lambda resulting in (minimum mse + 1SE) lasso_mod_1se <- lasso_mods[[2]]  # Training results with all lambdas lasso_cv <- lasso_mods[[3]]  # visualize lasso_cv: # get_model_plot(x_train_mat, y_train_mat, model = "lasso", ask = "plot") ridge_mods <-   get_model_plot(x_train_mat,                   y_train_mat,                   model = "ridge",                   ask = "modeling")  # model with lambda resulting in minimum mse ridge_mod <- ridge_mods[[1]]  # model with lambda resulting in (minimum mse + 1SE) ridge_mod_1se <- ridge_mods[[2]]  # Training results with all lambdas ridge_cv <- ridge_mods[[3]]  # visualize ridge_cv: # get_model_plot(x_train_mat, y_train_mat, model = "ridge", ask = "plot")

title: carpriceprediction-vignette
text: can use get_er_cv() combine results table. Note also contain OLS Full Regression comparison. Column Model model trained using training set; Column R_MSE square root mean prediction error using testing set.
code: get_er_cv(training_df_at, training_df_sub, kfolds = 10, lasso_cv, ridge_cv) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   Model                             R_MSE #>   <chr>                             <dbl> #> 1 LASSO Regression with minimum MSE  671. #> 2 LASSO Regression with 1SE MSE      810. #> 3 Ridge Regression with minimum MSE  658. #> 4 LASSO Regression with 1SE MSE      846. #> 5 OLS Full Regression               1052.

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: outlines propose change carpriceprediction. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("DSCI-310/dsci-310-group-07-pkg", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to carpriceprediction
text: Please note carpriceprediction project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Predict Car Price Based on Certain Charateristics
text: example, use actual automobile dataset. first 6 lines automobile follows:
code: #> # A tibble: 6 × 26 #>   symbol…¹ norma…² make  fuel-…³ aspir…⁴ num-o…⁵ body-…⁶ drive…⁷ engin…⁸ wheel…⁹ #>   <fct>      <dbl> <fct> <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>     <dbl> #> 1 3             NA alfa… gas     std     two     conver… rwd     front      88.6 #> 2 3             NA alfa… gas     std     two     conver… rwd     front      88.6 #> 3 1             NA alfa… gas     std     two     hatchb… rwd     front      94.5 #> 4 2            164 audi  gas     std     four    sedan   fwd     front      99.8 #> 5 2            164 audi  gas     std     four    sedan   4wd     front      99.4 #> 6 2             NA audi  gas     std     two     sedan   fwd     front      99.8 #> # … with 16 more variables: length <dbl>, width <dbl>, height <dbl>, #> #   `curb-weight` <dbl>, `engine-type` <fct>, `num-of-cylinders` <fct>, #> #   `engine-size` <dbl>, `fuel-system` <fct>, bore <dbl>, stroke <dbl>, #> #   `compression-ratio` <dbl>, horsepower <dbl>, `peak-rpm` <dbl>, #> #   `city-mpg` <dbl>, `highway-mpg` <dbl>, price <dbl>, and abbreviated #> #   variable names ¹​symboling, ²​`normalized-losses`, ³​`fuel-type`, ⁴​aspiration, #> #   ⁵​`num-of-doors`, ⁶​`body-style`, ⁷​`drive-wheels`, ⁸​`engine-location`, …

title: Predict Car Price Based on Certain Charateristics
code: (getR2(automobile,n = 2)) #>   r_sqr       names #> 1 0.796        make #> 2 0.761 engine-size plots <- plotAll(automobile, c("make","engine-size")) # `make` is a factor, hence show the barplot plots[[1]] # `engine-size` is continuous, henshow show the histogram and scatterplot with a linear regression line plots[[2]] plots[[3]]

title: Predict Car Price Based on Certain Charateristics
text: Lasso regression: Ridge regression: Performance different models:
code: # By specifying the set = "basic", the result contains all columns training_df<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"basic")[[1]] testing_df<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"basic")[[2]]   # By specifying the set = "at", the result contains all columns except ID training_df_at<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"at")[[1]] testing_df_at<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"at")[[2]]  # By specifying the set = "sub", the result contains columns except ID or categorical variables with more than 2 levels training_df_sub<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"sub")[[1]] testing_df_sub<-get_tr_tst(automobile,"sub")[[2]] # training matrices training_matrices <- get_trm_tsm(training_df_sub,                                   testing_df_sub,                                   set = "training") x_train_mat <- training_matrices[[1]] y_train_mat <- training_matrices[[2]]  # testing matrices testing_matrices <- get_trm_tsm(training_df_sub,                                  testing_df_sub,                                  set = "testing") x_test_mat <- testing_matrices[[1]] y_test_mat <- testing_matrices[[2]] # Lasso regression lasso_mods <-   get_model_plot(x_train_mat,                   y_train_mat,                   model = "lasso",                   ask = "modeling")  # model with lambda resulting in minimum mse lasso_mod <- lasso_mods[[1]]  # model with lambda resulting in (minimum mse + 1SE) lasso_mod_1se <- lasso_mods[[2]]  # Training results with all lambdas lasso_cv <- lasso_mods[[3]]  # visualize lasso_cv: # get_model_plot(x_train_mat, y_train_mat, model = "lasso", ask = "plot") ridge_mods <-   get_model_plot(x_train_mat,                   y_train_mat,                   model = "ridge",                   ask = "modeling")  # model with lambda resulting in minimum mse ridge_mod <- ridge_mods[[1]]  # model with lambda resulting in (minimum mse + 1SE) ridge_mod_1se <- ridge_mods[[2]]  # Training results with all lambdas ridge_cv <- ridge_mods[[3]]  # visualize ridge_cv: # get_model_plot(x_train_mat, y_train_mat, model = "ridge", ask = "plot") get_er_cv(training_df_at, training_df_sub, kfolds = 10, lasso_cv, ridge_cv) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   Model                             R_MSE #>   <chr>                             <dbl> #> 1 LASSO Regression with minimum MSE  671. #> 2 LASSO Regression with 1SE MSE      810. #> 3 Ridge Regression with minimum MSE  658. #> 4 LASSO Regression with 1SE MSE      846. #> 5 OLS Full Regression               1052.
